author: COMSOL
description: A cylindrical magnet falling through a copper tube induces eddy currents on the tube walls. The eddy currents, in turn, create a magnetic field that opposes the magnetic field of the magnet and induces a braking force that opposes the motion of the magnet. This opposing force increases with increasing velocity. Thus, there is a terminal velocity at which the magnetic braking force equals the force of gravity. The example computes the velocity of the magnet after it is dropped as it reaches its terminal velocity.
label: falling_magnet.mph
